module: CLK Module 3: Comparative Laws - Module 2: Contract Interpretation & Remedies

questions.question: What interpretive safeguard does Article 1344 of the Indonesian Civil Code provide when contract wording is unclear?

options.A: It instructs courts to adopt any interpretation that frustrates enforcement.
options.B: It requires that, where clauses admit several meanings, the interpretation that preserves enforceability of the contract must be preferred.
options.C: It compels judges to disregard party intention entirely.
options.D: It directs courts to follow foreign precedents instead of the code.

A.explanation: Article 1344 is designed to sustain, not derail, contractual effectiveness when text is unclear.

B.explanation: When multiple meanings are possible, courts choose the reading that keeps the agreement enforceable, aligning with the civil law priority of upholding the parties’ bargain.

C.explanation: Articles 1343–1351 emphasise discerning true party intention rather than discarding it.

D.explanation: Indonesian interpretation starts with the Civil Code and context, not foreign precedent.

questions.question: According to Jesa Triori’s commentary, what is the primary task when applying Articles 1343–1351 of the Indonesian Civil Code?

options.A: Identifying the party with the stronger bargaining position.
options.B: Discovering the parties’ common intention at the time the contract was concluded, using context and custom where necessary.
options.C: Prioritising literal word meanings irrespective of context.
options.D: Transposing English contract doctrines wholesale.

A.explanation: The Indonesian approach does not hinge on bargaining power; it centres on shared contractual intention.

B.explanation: Triori explains that courts reconstruct the parties’ mutual intention at formation using context, custom, and surrounding circumstances when wording is unclear.

C.explanation: Literal meaning yields once ambiguity exists; the Civil Code directs judges to consider broader context.

D.explanation: Indonesian courts rely on their own code-based doctrinal tools rather than importing English doctrines wholesale.

questions.question: What did Thai Supreme Court Judgment 1375/2505 demonstrate about customary practice in contract interpretation?

options.A: Customs can never supplement written contracts.
options.B: Even absent express terms, industry custom (tight packing of jute in freight forwarding) became part of the contract, and failure to comply constituted breach.
options.C: Courts disregard customs unless codified in statutes.
options.D: Customary practice only matters in criminal law.

A.explanation: Section 368 CCC expressly allows usage and custom to supplement contractual obligations.
A.note_link: Thai CCC s368 – Custom and Good Faith

B.explanation: Judgment 1375/2505 treated the industry custom of tightly packing jute as implied, and non-compliance was a breach under Section 368 CCC.
B.note_link: Thai CCC s368 – Custom and Good Faith

C.explanation: Thai courts can incorporate customary practices even when not codified elsewhere.
C.note_link: Thai CCC s368 – Custom and Good Faith

D.explanation: Customary usage informs civil contract disputes, particularly on performance standards.
D.note_link: Thai CCC s368 – Custom and Good Faith

questions.question: What principle did Thai Supreme Court Judgment 2210/2526 affirm regarding clear contractual wording?

options.A: That courts must always look beyond the written contract.
options.B: That when provisions are clear, parties may not adduce external evidence to contradict them, and courts need not interpret beyond the written terms.
options.C: That titles override substantive provisions.
options.D: That oral testimony automatically prevails over written clauses.

A.explanation: Thai courts resort to contextual evidence only where ambiguity exists; clear text stands on its own.

B.explanation: Judgment 2210/2526 confirms that unambiguous clauses bar contradictory extrinsic evidence, so courts need not reinterpret beyond the written words.

C.explanation: Headings do not override operative clauses; substance controls under Thai interpretation rules.

D.explanation: When wording is clear, the written provisions prevail; oral testimony cannot contradict them.

questions.question: How does Section 11 of the Thai CCC protect obligors when interpreting ambiguous clauses?

options.A: It favours creditors in all cases.
options.B: It mandates that, in cases of doubt, interpretation should be in favour of the party who bears the obligation, narrowing scope against the debtor absent clear words (e.g., mortgage guarantee case).
options.C: It allows courts to disregard the written contract entirely.
options.D: It requires debts to be expanded beyond the written text.

A.explanation: Section 11 protects debtors by resolving doubt in their favour, so it does not privilege creditors.

B.explanation: Thai courts construe uncertain obligations against the creditor, illustrated by the mortgage guarantee decision limiting liability to the debtor’s own debts.

C.explanation: Interpretation respects the document but narrows ambiguous burdens rather than disregarding the text.

D.explanation: Section 11 curtails rather than expands unclear obligations, ensuring debtors are not saddled with unexpected liabilities.

questions.question: What did Thai Supreme Court Judgment 478/2544 illustrate about the power of good faith to override literal terms?

options.A: Good faith is irrelevant once a clause is written.
options.B: Even where usage was unspecified, good faith and ordinary custom required allowing vehicular use of a right-of-way, so narrowing it to pedestrian access breached the contract.
options.C: Good faith only applies to tort claims.
options.D: Good faith excuses non-performance by default.

A.explanation: Thai law allows good faith and custom to supplement written terms when necessary to achieve their purpose.

B.explanation: Judgment 478/2544 required vehicular access because ordinary use and good faith demanded it, even though the clause was silent about vehicles.

C.explanation: Good faith duties operate across contractual performance, not solely in tort contexts.

D.explanation: Good faith shapes how obligations are fulfilled; it does not grant automatic excuses for non-performance.

questions.question: How do Articles 10–14 of the Thai CCC assist in filling contractual gaps when intentions cannot be ascertained?

options.A: They compel courts to void the contract.
options.B: They provide default interpretive rules (e.g., prefer effective meanings, favour obligors, written words over figures, lowest amount when conflicting, Thai text prevails), ensuring predictable outcomes when intent is unclear.
options.C: They direct courts to apply foreign law.
options.D: They require parties to renegotiate before litigation.

A.explanation: Sections 10–14 exist to uphold contracts by clarifying doubtful terms, not to void agreements.

B.explanation: The code supplies default tie-breakers—choose meanings that render terms effective, favour obligors, prioritise words, select lowest amounts, and default to Thai text—when intent cannot be resolved.

C.explanation: These are domestic statutory defaults; they do not authorise applying foreign law.

D.explanation: Parties need not renegotiate before courts apply the code’s default interpretation rules.

questions.question: Why did the Istanbul tribunal require claimants to elect remedies promptly under Article 125 of the Turkish Code of Obligations (TCO)?

options.A: Because Turkish law forbids damages claims altogether.
options.B: Because once a party insists on performance (by not electing rescission/positive or negative damages), it is deemed to have chosen performance and may later recover only delay damages; failure to elect barred their positive/negative damages claim.
options.C: Because Turkish law automatically awards punitive damages.
options.D: Because Article 125 applies only to tort claims.

A.explanation: Turkish law still allows damages, but the election must be made promptly under Article 125.

B.explanation: Failing to elect rescission or damages signals an insistence on performance, leaving only delay damages later, which barred the claimant’s positive/negative damages claim.

C.explanation: Article 125 does not create punitive damages; it governs selection among performance, positive, or negative damages.

D.explanation: Article 125 addresses contractual remedies rather than tort liabilities.

questions.question: How do Turkish positive and negative damages differ under Articles 126 and 125(3) TCO?

options.A: Positive damages refer to emotional distress; negative damages to punitive awards.
options.B: Positive damages measure expectation interest (difference between contract price and fair market value at termination), while negative damages approximate reliance interest (position had the contract never been made).
options.C: Positive damages are unavailable; only negative damages exist.
options.D: Negative damages equal double the contract price.

A.explanation: Positive and negative damages address economic loss categories, not emotional distress or punitive awards.

B.explanation: Positive damages capture expectation loss (contract price vs market value), while negative damages restore the pre-contract position after rescission.

C.explanation: Both expectation and reliance measures are available in Turkish contract law.

D.explanation: Negative damages do not double amounts; they reimburse the loss incurred by entering the contract.

questions.question: Why did the tribunal reject the sellers’ damages calculation in the Turkish case study?

options.A: Because Turkish law disallows comparing contract price to subsequent sale price years later; damages must reflect value at termination or the position absent the contract, not later market movements.
options.B: Because damages are never available for wrongful termination.
options.C: Because Turkish law ignores expectation interest entirely.
options.D: Because the tribunal lacked jurisdiction over damages claims.

A.explanation: Article 126 measures positive damages at termination; using a later resale price years afterward misstates loss, so the tribunal rejected that methodology.

B.explanation: Turkish law does allow damages for wrongful termination when calculated under Articles 125–126.

C.explanation: Expectation losses are recognised as positive damages; the problem was the valuation date, not the head of loss.

D.explanation: Jurisdiction was accepted; only the damages calculation was criticised.

questions.question: How does the Indonesian Civil Code treat contracts concluded in a foreign language without an Indonesian version, in light of the 2023 Supreme Court circular?

options.A: All foreign-language contracts remain automatically void.
options.B: Contracts lacking an Indonesian version can only be annulled if the absence resulted from bad faith; genuine mistakes may be cured, reflecting later clarification of Law No. 24/2009.
options.C: The circular declared the language law unconstitutional.
options.D: Foreign-language contracts are now unenforceable under any circumstance.

A.explanation: The circular removed automatic nullity; only bad-faith omissions risk annulment.

B.explanation: Contracts without an Indonesian version are voidable only if the omission stems from bad faith, consistent with Regulation No. 63/2019 and the 2023 Supreme Court circular.

C.explanation: The circular interprets but does not invalidate Law No. 24/2009.

D.explanation: Foreign-language contracts remain enforceable when parties comply or cure good-faith omissions.

questions.question: How does Section 12 of the Thai CCC resolve discrepancies between amounts written in words and numerals?

options.A: Numerals always prevail over words.
options.B: Words control over numerals when intent cannot be ascertained, ensuring the written-out amount governs.
options.C: Courts must average the two amounts.
options.D: The larger figure automatically applies.

A.explanation: Section 12 expressly favours spelled-out words over numerals when figures conflict.

B.explanation: Thai Supreme Court precedent confirms that words control over digits when intent is unclear, providing certainty for ambiguous amounts.

C.explanation: The CCC does not instruct courts to average conflicting amounts.

D.explanation: Section 12 does not automatically select the larger number; it prioritises the written-out amount.

questions.question: What interpretive default does Section 13 of the Thai CCC impose when multiple conflicting figures appear?

options.A: Select the highest figure to maximise compensation.
options.B: Apply the lowest amount if real intent cannot be ascertained, reducing exposure for the obligor.
options.C: Discard the contract entirely.
options.D: Invoke punitive surcharges.

A.explanation: Section 13 resolves inconsistent figures by selecting the lowest amount, not the highest.

B.explanation: The provision protects obligors by defaulting to the lowest conflicting amount when intent cannot otherwise be ascertained.

C.explanation: These interpretive defaults keep the contract operative rather than voiding it.

D.explanation: The statute does not impose punitive surcharges; it narrows liability to the minimum figure.

questions.question: Why does Section 14 of the Thai CCC give precedence to the Thai language in multi-language contracts?

options.A: Because foreign languages are prohibited in Thai contracts.
options.B: Because if parties cannot ascertain which language prevails, Thai text governs, providing certainty in domestic transactions.
options.C: Because Thai courts refuse to read foreign-language documents.
options.D: Because Thai text always supersedes even when parties agree otherwise.

A.explanation: Section 14 does not forbid foreign-language contracts; it supplies a default when no language is specified.

B.explanation: If parties fail to nominate a governing language, Thai text prevails by default, ensuring certainty in domestic dealings.

C.explanation: Courts can review foreign versions but fall back on Section 14 when intent cannot be resolved.

D.explanation: Parties are free to agree on a different prevailing language expressly; Section 14 is only a default.

questions.question: How does the civil law preference for specific performance interact with the Collingridge dilemma in technology regulation?

options.A: It makes regulation unnecessary.
options.B: It reflects civil law’s commitment to actual performance, but regulators still face timing challenges (uncertain impacts early, entrenchment later); specific performance remains conditioned on possibility and proportionality.
options.C: It mandates immediate regulation regardless of information gaps.
options.D: It eliminates the need for damages calculations.

A.explanation: Even with strong specific performance, regulators still face the Collingridge timing dilemma.

B.explanation: Civil law prioritises actual performance, yet courts temper it where enforcement is impossible or disproportionate, leaving regulatory timing problems unresolved.

C.explanation: Specific performance does not mandate regulators to act prematurely; timing judgments still depend on information availability.

D.explanation: Damages remain crucial when specific performance is declined, so calculations still matter.

questions.question: What distinguishes the civil law approach to damages from the common law’s reliance on Hadley v Baxendale?

options.A: Civil law ignores foreseeability entirely.
options.B: Civil law codes often specify recoverable heads (actual loss, lost profits) directly, whereas common law uses precedent like Hadley v Baxendale to limit consequential damages to foreseeable losses contemplated by the parties.
options.C: Common law denies damages altogether.
options.D: Civil law awards punitive damages for breach routinely.

A.explanation: Civil codes often include foreseeability thresholds when spelling out recoverable loss categories.

B.explanation: Civil law typically lists recoverable heads (actual loss, lost profits) in the code, while common law relies on precedents like Hadley v Baxendale to define foreseeability limits on consequential damages.

C.explanation: Common law recognises substantial compensatory damages; it does not deny them wholesale.

D.explanation: Civil law rarely awards punitive damages for breach; expectation measures remain compensatory.

questions.question: How does the Indonesian doctrine of adequate causation in Article 1365 apply to contract damages?

options.A: It requires exact knowledge of the specific harm form.
options.B: It deems a party liable if the harm was foreseeable as a general result of the act; precise form need not be foreseen, aligning with a foreseeability standard similar to common law.
options.C: It imposes strict liability regardless of foreseeability.
options.D: It excuses liability whenever the precise quantum is debated.

A.explanation: Adequate causation does not demand precision about the exact form of harm; general foreseeability suffices.

B.explanation: Article 1365 liability arises when the type of harm was foreseeable as a probable consequence, even if the precise manifestation was unknown.

C.explanation: Adequate causation still requires fault; it does not impose strict liability.

D.explanation: Disputes about quantum do not automatically excuse liability once causation is adequate.

questions.question: What comparative insight arises from the Istanbul tribunal’s rejection of delayed-market damages and English law’s expectation measure?

options.A: English law also disallows expectation damages.
options.B: Both systems emphasise valuation at breach (contract price vs contemporaneous market value) rather than post hoc market fluctuations, showing convergent logic despite doctrinal differences.
options.C: Civil law focuses solely on reliance interest.
options.D: Common law mandates using later sale prices.

A.explanation: English law firmly applies expectation damages; it does not disallow them.

B.explanation: Both the Turkish tribunal and English precedent value loss at breach, rejecting post-breach market swings as the primary benchmark.

C.explanation: Civil law recognises expectation loss statutorily; it does not confine recovery to reliance only.

D.explanation: Common law does not mandate using later sale prices; breach-date value governs in both systems.

questions.question: How do civil law systems handle mitigation duties compared with English law?

options.A: Civil law never imposes mitigation duties.
options.B: English law requires mitigation for contract breaches; civil law jurisdictions vary—some (like France) hesitate to impose broad mitigation duties, though reimbursement for mitigation costs is recognised when undertaken.
options.C: Civil law imposes strict mitigation duties with punitive consequences.
options.D: English law rejects mitigation entirely.

A.explanation: Civil law does recognise mitigation in targeted areas; it is not entirely absent.

B.explanation: English law obliges claimants to mitigate, while civil jurisdictions vary—French courts resist a broad duty yet reimburse reasonable mitigation expenses.

C.explanation: Civil law does not enforce mitigation through punitive measures; duties, where recognised, remain compensatory.

D.explanation: Mitigation is a central feature of English contract damages analysis.

questions.question: What comparative lesson emerges from the Turkish damages election rule for practitioners drafting contracts in mixed legal environments?

options.A: Practitioners can delay remedy elections indefinitely without risk.
options.B: Contracts should stipulate remedy election procedures and deadlines explicitly to avoid statutory default rules (like Article 125 TCO) limiting remedies when parties delay decisions.
options.C: Civil law contracts never require remedial elections.
options.D: Common law contracts forbid choice of remedies clauses.

A.explanation: Article 125 shows that delaying an election can restrict remedies, so practitioners cannot postpone indefinitely without risk.

B.explanation: Drafting clear election procedures and deadlines prevents statutory defaults from narrowing available remedies when parties operate across mixed legal systems.

C.explanation: Civil codes often mandate remedy elections; contracts must take those defaults into account.

D.explanation: Common law agreements can include choice-of-remedy clauses, so there is no prohibition on tailoring elections.
